attributes.title: Immigration and Social Welfare Survey Experiment

q1.value: Immigration and Social Welfare Survey Experiment

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: What makes some Americans assume that social welfare programs will benefit immigrants at the expense of native-born Americans? How do these assumptions shape their attitudes about social welfare policy? With the increasing ethnic heterogeneity of the United States, and the growing salience of immigration in our politics, these are timely and important questions. European scholars have found that increasing ethnic heterogeneity brought about by immigration has partially undermined native support for the welfare state, even in robust social democracies.  In the U.S. context, immigration scholars in sociology and political science have uncovered an important role for immigration attitudes in social policy, perhaps even greater than the role of racial attitudes. To advance the study of this phenomenon, scholars need strong evidence on the nature of the relationship between immigration attitudes and welfare attitudes, analogous to the older and more developed literature on race and welfare in the U.S.. Under what conditions do Americans think about immigrants when they think about social welfare policy? Are they more likely to do so when they perceive immigrants as a threat? If so, is this threat best understood as cultural or economic? In this study, I will use a randomized survey experiment to answer these questions.

q16.value: H1 - Americans who are primed to think about immigrants in a context of cultural or demographic threat will be more likely to assume that social welfare policies benefit immigrants to the exclusion of native-born Americans than will those who are not primed to think about immigrants. H2 - Americans who are primed to think about immigrants in a context of economic threat or fiscal burden will be more likely to assume that social welfare policies benefit immigrants to the exclusion of native-born Americans than will those who are not primed to think about immigrants. H3a - The effect of the cultural/demographic threat prime on the assumption that social welfare policies benefit immigrants to the exclusion of native-born Americans will be strongest among those most opposed to immigration. H3b - The effect of the economic/fiscal threat prime on the assumption that social welfare policies benefit immigrants to the exclusion of native-born Americans will be strongest among those most opposed to immigration. H4a - The effect of the cultural/demographic threat prime on the assumption that social welfare policies benefit immigrants to the exclusion of native-born Americans will be strongest among those who live in regions where Latinos or Hispanics make up a relatively large part of the population. H4b - The effect of the economic/fiscal threat prime on the assumption that social welfare policies benefit immigrants to the exclusion of native-born Americans will be strongest among those who live in regions where Latinos or Hispanics make up a relatively large part of the population. H5 - When Americans assume a social welfare policy benefits immigrants to the exclusion of native-born Americans, their attitudes about immigration will become more important to their views of that social welfare policy as compared to similar Americans who do not make this assumption. Additional research questions (no directional hypotheses) Q1 - Which prime has a larger effect on the assumption that immigrants will benefit to the exclusion of native-born Americans: the cultural/demographic threat prime or the economic/fiscal threat prime? Q2 - Do the primes have different effects among white and non-white individuals?

q17.value: The hypotheses will be tested using a survey experiment on 2000 American respondents (recruited by Qualtrics) with three conditions: a cultural/demographic threat condition, an economic/fiscal threat condition, and a control condition. The cultural/demographic threat condition will include a priming question on offering driver’s license tests in language other than English, with statistics on the growth of the non-English speaking population in the US. The economic/fiscal threat condition will include a priming question on unauthorized immigrants paying less than native-born Americans in taxes. The control questions will deal with minimum ages for driver’s license and tax enforcement, with no mention of immigration-related issues. The key dependent variables will be assumptions about what groups benefit from a generic described social welfare policy and the respondent’s level of support for that policy. Respondents will have the option to select from a large list of potential beneficiary groups (racial and ethnic categories, economic categories, etc.) and select as many groups as they wish. The key dependent variable will be a dichotomous variable equal to 1 if the respondent selects “immigrants” but not “Americans born in the United States.” Policy support will be measured with a seven-point Likert scale. Immigration attitudes (see H3a & H3b) will be measured with a five-item battery of immigration policy questions from the American National Election Study. Regional Latino/Hispanic population (H4a & H4b) will be measured using American Community Survey Zip Code Tabulation Area estimates, or estimates at another geographic level if this proves unworkable. H1 and H2 will be tested (and Q1 answered) with simple difference-of-proportions tests between treatment groups. H3-H5 will be tested (and Q2 answered) with logistic and OLS regressions with interaction terms of treatment indicators and the relevant independent variables. For more detail on treatments and variables, see the attached survey instrument.

attributes.title: How does argument disagreement affect posterior beliefs?

q1.value: How does argument disagreement affect posterior beliefs?

q2.value: Dominik Duell | Catherine Hafer | Dimitri Landa

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: A large literature asserts that individuals tend to ignore information that runs counter to their prior beliefs and that those may even be reinforced upon being exposed to counter-attitudinal evidence (Taber/Lodge 2006, Lau/Redlawsk 2006, Nyhan/Reifler 2010). That conclusion, however, appears not to condition on whether the presented arguments are perceived as persuasive or distinguish between arguments and other kinds of information (opinions or facts). These distinctions are important because influential theories in political science and philosophy anticipate opposite effects from individuals’ exposure to unpersuasive to them, yet credible, arguments. In the first stage of a survey experiment, we elicit subjects’ opinion and their confidence in that opinion on five issues. In the second stage of the experiment, conducted three weeks later, we first present subjects with arguments running counter to their stated opinion (from the first stage) on two randomly chosen issues. On the screen where subjects are given the arguments, they are also asked to indicate whether they find the provided argument persuasive and for their reasoning to explain that judgment. Everyone who participates in the second stage is treated with arguments on two issues (and enters the control group for the other issues). We, further, randomly assign a subset of subjects to a "no argument" treatment but give them the following text on the screen (for example): "Consider the following question: Do you think affirmative action in college admissions is a desirable tool for ensuring equal opportunity?“ And, supposing the subject answered affirmative in the first stage, s/he is now asked: "Please write down your best argument to support your position..." Finally, all subjects are again asked about their issue opinion and confidence in that opinion and self-report their news consumption, political knowledge, political ideology, and familiarity with the issues.

q16.value: The theoretical framework that supports the hypotheses below is based on the formal analysis of effects of argumentation in the model of deliberation as self-discovery by Hafer and Landa (2013; 2018) and Dickson, Hafer, and Landa (2009). Main hypotheses (Dickson, Hafer, and Landa 2009): H1: Conditional on there being residual uncertainty about preferred policy, one's confidence in the (prior) opinion increases after exposure to a counter-attitudinal argument that s/he finds not persuasive. H2: Conditional on there being residual uncertainty about preferred policy, one's confidence in the (prior) opinion decreases or the opinion is reversed after exposure to a counter-attitudinal argument that s/he finds persuasive. Heterogeneous treatment effects: We expect differences in treatment effects by news consumption and political knowledge. In particular, consistent with Hafer and Landa (2013 and 2018), we expect the following: H3a: The increase in confidence after hearing a non-persuasive counter-attitudinal argument (H1) will be stronger for subjects who report high news consumption and who are politically more knowledgeable than for those who report low news consumption and who are less politically knowledgeable. Note, there is a competing effect: H3b: The increase in confidence after hearing a non-persuasive counter-attitudinal argument (H1) will be weaker for those who are politically more knowledgeable, given that they are more likely to have seen the argument in the treatment, and so their posterior may not be as responsive as a result. To separate those two competing effects, we elicit whether subjects indicate to have been familiar with the argument presented to them. We expect support for H3b only for subjects who self-report high levels of familiarity with the argument.

q17.value: The hypotheses will be tested by a between subject comparison of the within-subject difference prior-posterior confidence in the stated opinion of control and treatment group. We will compute the difference in stated issue opinion between treatment (receiving the counter-attitudinal argument) and control group in the within-subject difference between prior and posterior confidence in the stated issue opinion. The difference-in-difference regression will also include terms indicating the order in which the two treatment issues were seen by the subject, what issues form that pair of treatment arguments seen by the subject, the subjects’ self-reported news consumption, political knowledge, political ideology, and familiarity with the arguments as well as an indicator of the order in which the non-treatment issue opinions and confidence in those stated opinions are elicited. For estimation of sub-group effects, we compute the difference-in-difference estimator for median-split groups of low/high news consumption, low/high political knowledge, and low, medium, high familiarity with the argument separately as well as estimate the interaction effect of a treatment dummy and the full range of values on the news consumption/political knowledge/familiarity with argument variables. The difference-in-difference regression will also include terms indicating the order in which the issues were seen by the subject, the issue pair seen by the subject, and the subjects’ self-reported news consumption, political knowledge, political ideology, and familiarity with the arguments as well as an indicator of the order of the non-treatment issues seen by the subject. For estimation of sub-group effects, we compute the difference-in-difference estimator for median-split groups of low/high news consumption, low/high political knowledge, and low, medium, high familiarity with the argument separately as well as estimate the interaction effect of a treatment dummy and the full range of values on the news consumption/political knowledge/familiarity with argument variables.

attributes.title: The gender gap, violence, and non-state governance in Haiti

q1.value: The gender gap, violence, and non-state governance in Haiti

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Within a household survey in Port-au-Prince, we embedded randomized survey primes to study the sources of foreign policy opinions around war, attitudes about how gang violence should be addressed, and attitudes and preferences about local and national governance, including governance by non-state actors (including gangs).

q16.value: Core hypotheses around (1) mechanisms for a gender gap in security preferences; (2) how citizen support for gangs affects attitudes about gang violence resolution; (3) reporting of provision of non-state services. More detail provided in attachment

q17.value: Via household survey conducted in Port-au-Prince, Haiti. Outcome questions include those around (1) attitudes about the use of force, (2) how gang violence should be addressed, (3) reports of gang and non-state service provision and overall views of gangs. See attached plan for more detail.

attributes.title: Awareness of History and Behavior of Socially Excluded Groups

q1.value: Awareness of History and Behavior of Socially Excluded Groups

q5.value: The author thanks the Graduate School at Brown University for the generous funding they provided to the project through the Global Mobility Fellowship.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: In a previous study conducted by Diego Ramos-Toro, it was found that descendants of those who suffered leprosy were significantly more altruistic, more parochial (i.e. biased in favor of ingroup members), and significantly more fearful of modern medicine when compared to individuals who grew up in identical climatic and socioeconomic contexts. The fact that having an ancestor who was excluded predicts these behaviors indicates that there is a cultural component driving the results. Two questions thus arise: What is the role of awareness of historical issues in materializing the set of results find earlier? Are different components of history eliciting different types of behavior?

q16.value: There are three hypotheses to be tested: 1) Awareness of history of exclusion elicits ingroup favoritism. In this case, ingroup favoritism will be captured by the difference between how much a participant decides to allocate to an anonymous receiver from the same municipality and how much the same participant allocates to an anonymous receiver in a distant municipality 2) Awareness of the historical role of medicine in excluding lepers elicits mistrust towards medicine and doctors. In this case, trust in doctors will be captured by survey measures (reported trust in doctors), while trust in medicine will be captured by the take-up of a voucher that will be given to all participants and that may be redeemed in exchange for a free pill against stomach worms in a local pharmacy 3) Awareness of botanical history elicits no distinct behavior in any dimension On top of that, the protocol will allow to corroborate earlier findings with different outcomes, namely the finding that having an excluded (leper) ancestry predicts ingroup favoritism and predicts mistrust in doctors and in medicine.

q17.value: A group of research assistants will visit and recruit participants in Agua de Dios, a former leper colony in Colombia. These will be randomly allocated to one of the following groups: Group 1: Participants who will answer the survey without additional information Group 2 (Treatment 1): Participants who, before answering any question, will listen while the research team reads a small paragraph discussing the historical exclusion of lepers in the world. Group 3 (Treatment 2): Participants who, before answering any question, will listen while the research team reads a small paragraph discussing the historical medical misinformation regarding leprosy Group 4 (Treatment 3): Participants who will listen while the research team reads a text about the history of an emblematic tree in the region Subjects will provide survey responses on their demographic characteristics and on their views regarding various types of professionals. All participants will be automatically enrolled in a lottery with a prize of COP $800,000 (~230 USD). As a part of the survey, participants will be asked how much they would be willing to give away to (1) a random receiver in the same municipality and (2) a random receiver in a distant municipality. The lottery will be given to the participant who wins it, and the amounts that she reported in the survey will in fact be deducted from her prize and given to anonymous receivers. Finally, by the end of the survey each participant will receive a voucher that may be redeemed in exchange for a free pill against stomach worms. The responses and actions of the groups will be compared. Participants assigned to group 2 are expected to display ingroup favoritism significantly more than other participant. Similarly, participants assigned to group 3 are expected to display significantly less trust towards physicians and modern medicine.

attributes.title: Informality, Taxation, and Politics: Evidence from a New Democracy

q1.value: Informality, Taxation, and Politics: Evidence from a New Democracy

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: A long literature defends the claim that taxation and government accountability go hand in hand either because taxation gives citizens more bargaining power, raises expectations for the provision of services and the good governance, or increases willingness to engage in costly action. But this virtuous relationship between taxpaying and democratic accountability may be conditional. First, if voters pay taxes in an unsystematic, unobserved, or informal way, expectations of benefits and subsequent pressure on the government may, in turn, be dampened. Second, if taxpayers perceive their experience paying taxes as independent from those of others in a similar economic situation, they may fail to coordinate on voting on fiscal issues. This project seeks to connect the literature on taxation and accountability to the phenomenon of clientelistic electoral strategies -- the norm in many young democracies. Much ink has been spilled over how to break the clientelitsic equilibrium -- namely, the situation in which political parties campaign on the promise of particularistic transfers rather than on programmatic issues, and in return, citizens only hold governments to account for these targeted, one-off transfers rather than more universal policies. The historical record demonstrates that the transition to programmatic politics in advanced democracies often relied upon broad-based constituencies of middle class urbanites who were no longer satisfied with plum patronage jobs and transfers but instead began to clamor for universalistic policies such as workers rights and a social safety net. In the young democracies of some developing countries, the middle class is swelling as it reaps the benefits of steady growth and development in the post-structural adjustment era. Will this group mimic the middle classes in the US and England -- calling upon the government to reform and provide better services? So far, the answer has been no. This project proposes and interrogates the intuition that one reason for this is the informal nature of taxation in developing countries. Whether and how citizens pay taxes, and their perceptions of belonging to a group of like-minded taxpayers, conditions their political demands and the likelihood of voting on programmatic issues. For class consciousness to emerge and translate into coordinated pressure on the government, a group of individuals must first see themselves as such. I seek to show that in one stable, developing democracy -- Senegal, this is not the case. While there is a growing group of urbanites in the capital who generate enough income to satisfy their most basic demands and thus share second-order preferences such as improved education and opportunities for their children, better infrastructure and services to support their businesses, this group is fractionalized and does not perceive these commonalities. One reason for this appears to be the uneven way in which members of this so-called middle class interact with the state. While there is a more traditional middle class group of salaried individuals working in the private and public sector who often have unions and shared experiences, this group is quite small. The second, much larger group is comprised of small businesses and individual entrepreneurs, the vast majority of which exist in the informal sector. While salaried individuals are taxed regularly and systematically in accordance with the fiscal code, informal sector business owners and entrepreneurs are taxed in an erratic and informal way by the state that is often outside standard and transparent fiscal processes. Not only are the experiences of these two groups substantively different, but the informal and unsystematic nature of taxation in the latter group does not lend itself to coordination. Members of this group have little information about how others like themselves experience taxation, and since their experience is unsystematic, they have no reason to assume the experience of others will look the same. The purpose of the present data collection exercise is to validate some of these assumptions and further examine the importance of the link between taxation, class consciousness, and political participation. Specifically, I will ask four related research questions. First, do citizens presently condition their vote on fiscal policy decisions, and is this conditional on being in the formal sector? Second, does priming taxation or making certain taxes more salient change the way in which voters conceive of demands on the government or make electoral decisions? Third, does priming the ability of like-minded voters to coordinate on shared interests influence the nature of demands on government or the way in which voters formulate electoral preferences? And finally, does providing information about the costs and benefits of formalization make formalization more attractive for the informal sector?

q16.value: Hypothesis 1: Salaried members who formally pay taxes will have a qualitatively different set of demands of the government – more programmatic in nature – relative to informal sector members who informally and unsystematically pay taxes, in spite of both saying they are able to meet basic needs. They will also be more likely to vote along programmatic lines. Hypothesis 2 Salaried members who formally pay taxes will believe the government to whom they pay tax is less corrupt and more responsive relative to informal sector members who informally and unsystematically pay taxes. Hypothesis 3 Priming individuals to think about the taxes they pay will induce them to value transparency from government more. Hypothesis 4 Priming informal sector individuals to think about the taxes they pay will induce them to rate the government as less capable, while it will not have this effect on salaried individuals. Hypothesis 5 Priming salaried individuals to think about the taxes they pay will induce them to demand even more from government or become more dissatisfied with its performance and vote more along programmatic lines, while priming informal sector individuals to consider their tax payments will not have these effects. Hypothesis 6 Making salient a fiscal policy that has net benefits for an individual will increase support for the incumbent, but only if the individual pays taxes in the formal sector. Hypothesis 7 Bringing people into the tax base activates them politically, increasing expectations or holding the government more responsible. Hypothesis 8 Telling informal sector entrepreneurs about their tax obligation were they to obtain formal status, along with the decreased tax rate for that group, should lead them to respond more positively to fiscal policy, increasing their support for the incumbent. Hypothesis 9 Providing information about formal tax obligations along with information about the costs and benefits to formalize will increase interest in formalization. Hypothesis 10 Giving members of a formally taxed group information about the size of the “middle class” coalition that could potentially benefit from the 2013 legislation will provide a coordinating mechanism for a political response to the policy, thus increasing the political salience of fiscal policy and programmatic politics in general. Hypothesis 11 Giving members of an informally taxed group information about their tax obligation under the law (either the CGU or VAT), along with the information that a large proportion of others are in their same position, will provide a coordinating mechanism for political activity among those similarly frustrated by the status quo, thus increasing political engagement.

q17.value: To test Hypothesis 1, I will compare responses across participant types to questions about the most important public service expected of each level of government (national and local). I expect responses of the formal sector to be more programmatic in nature. I will also provide a candidate vignette comparing two incumbents – one who performed well on the programmatic dimension, another who performed well on personalistic dimension. After eliciting their preferred candidate, I will elicit the respondent’s willingness to pay to stay with their preferred incumbent (or willingness to accept money to change to the other party). I expect members of the informal sector to have a higher willingness to pay to stay with the programmatic candidate. (prioritynat, priority com, vignette) To test Hypothesis 2, I will compare responses across participant types to questions about how much of the budget they expect each level of government to spend on public goods (relative to corrupt spending). To get at responsiveness, I will examine matches between what public services respondents prioritize and what services they think the government will actually spend new budget money on. (publicgoods, publicgoodscom; capacity; match between priority and spendon) To test Hypothesis 3, I will compare responses across primed and non-primed individuals to a question eliciting the extent to which they value transparency. (transparency) To test Hypothesis 4, I will compare within-group responses across primed and non-primed individuals to a question eliciting the capacity of the level of government to which they pay most taxes – national for formal sector and local for informal sector. (capacity) To test Hypothesis 5, I will compare within-group responses across primed and non-primed individuals to questions about satisfaction with both levels of government. I will also use the vignette and willingness to pay questions to assess voting along the programmatic dimension. (satisfynat, satisfyloc, vignette) To test Hypotheses 6, I will compare within-group responses across T1 and Control respondents to questions about satisfaction with the performance of the incumbent president (this will be asked both in the baseline following treatment and in the endline – the latter to determine whether there are longer term effects) and self-reported voting with the incumbent coalition in the end line. I will additionally assess impact on turnout by asking about likelihood of turnout in the baseline and self-reported actual turnout in the endline. Finally, to get at mechanisms, I will assess whether perceived fairness of the tax system increased (post-treatment in baseline and endline to get at long-term effects) and whether respondents think they will (baseline) or actually did (endline) base their vote in the legislative election partly on fiscal policy. (performancepost (controlling for satisfynat – prior satisfaction with gov), incumbentvote, turnout2017pre, turnout2017post, taxfairpre, fiscalvote) To check whether respondents are indeed learning new information, I will examine prior knowledge of the 2013 legislation in T1 and Control. If there is sufficient variation in baseline knowledge, I will condition treatment effects on prior knowledge. (legknow, legprior) To test Hypotheses 7, I will compare responses across T2 and Control respondents to questions about satisfaction with the performance of the incumbent president and self-reported voting with the incumbent coalition in the endline, and to questions about prospective and actual turnout decisions. Additionally, to get at mechanisms, I will ask whether perceived fairness of the tax system decreased and whether respondents think they will (baseline) or actually did (endline) base their vote in the legislative election partly on fiscal policy. (performancepost (controlling for satisfynat – prior satisfaction with gov), incumbentvote, turnout2017pre, turnout2017post, taxfairpre, fiscalvote) To check whether respondents are indeed learning new information, I will examine prior knowledge of the rate and global amount of the VAT payments. If there is sufficient variation in baseline knowledge, I will condition treatment effects on prior knowledge. (vatpredict, vatbudget) To test Hypothesis 8, I will compare responses across T3 and Control respondents to questions about satisfaction with the performance of the incumbent president and self-reported voting with the incumbent coalition in the endline, and to questions about prospective and actual turnout decisions. Additionally, I will ask whether perceived fairness of the tax system increased and whether respondents think they will (baseline) or actually did (endline) base their vote in the legislative election partly on fiscal policy. (performancepost (controlling for satisfynat – prior satisfaction with gov), incumbentvote, turnout2017pre, turnout2017post, taxfairpre, fiscalvote) To check whether respondents are indeed learning new information, I will examine prior knowledge of the CGU. If there is sufficient variation in baseline knowledge, I will condition treatment effects on prior knowledge. (CGU) To test Hypothesis 9, I will compare differences in responses across T3 and Control respondents between stated likelihood of formalization in the baseline (priors) and endline (posteriors) and whether higher taxes are among the costs they perceive to formalizing their business. At the close of the endline survey, I will provide respondents with a phone number to call to receive more information about formalizing their business. I will use this as a revealed preference measure of interest in formalization. (nineapost controlling for nineapre; calling to receive more information about formalization) To test Hypothesis 10, I will compare responses across T1 + Coordination and T1 Only respondents among formal sector participants to questions about voting along fiscal policy lines and self-reported voting with the incumbent coalition in the endline. I will additionally assess impact on turnout by asking about likelihood of turnout in the baseline and self-reported actual turnout in the endline. Because voting as a larger bloc could facilitate voting along programmatic rather than personalistic lines, I will additionally assess any impact on the willingness to pay question following the candidate vignette. (fiscalvote, incumbentvote, turnout2017pre, turnout2017post, vignette) To test Hypothesis 11, I will compare responses across T2 and T3 (combined) + Coordination and T2 and T3 (combined) + No Coordination respondents among informal sector participants to questions about voting along fiscal policy lines and self-reported voting with the incumbent coalition in the endline. I will additionally assess impact on turnout by asking about likelihood of turnout in the baseline and self-reported actual turnout in the endline. Because voting as a larger bloc could facilitate voting along programmatic rather than personalistic lines, I will additionally assess any impact on the willingness to pay question following the candidate vignette. (fiscalvote, incumbentvote, turnout2017pre, turnout2017post, vignette) To assess whether updating is occurring within both group types for the Coordination treatment, I will measure perceived size of the middle class (relative to the poor) as well as the largest taxpaying group at both baseline (pre-treatment) and endline. (percentmiddlepost-percentmiddlepre, largestgroup)

registration_responses.q1: Informality, Taxation, and Politics: Evidence from a New Democracy
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to assignment of treatment
registration_responses.q15: A long literature defends the claim that taxation and government accountability go hand in hand either because taxation gives citizens more bargaining power, raises expectations for the provision of services and the good governance, or increases willingness to engage in costly action. But this virtuous relationship between taxpaying and democratic accountability may be conditional. First, if voters pay taxes in an unsystematic, unobserved, or informal way, expectations of benefits and subsequent pressure on the government may, in turn, be dampened. Second, if taxpayers perceive their experience paying taxes as independent from those of others in a similar economic situation, they may fail to coordinate on voting on fiscal issues. This project seeks to connect the literature on taxation and accountability to the phenomenon of clientelistic electoral strategies -- the norm in many young democracies. Much ink has been spilled over how to break the clientelitsic equilibrium -- namely, the situation in which political parties campaign on the promise of particularistic transfers rather than on programmatic issues, and in return, citizens only hold governments to account for these targeted, one-off transfers rather than more universal policies. The historical record demonstrates that the transition to programmatic politics in advanced democracies often relied upon broad-based constituencies of middle class urbanites who were no longer satisfied with plum patronage jobs and transfers but instead began to clamor for universalistic policies such as workers rights and a social safety net. In the young democracies of some developing countries, the middle class is swelling as it reaps the benefits of steady growth and development in the post-structural adjustment era. Will this group mimic the middle classes in the US and England -- calling upon the government to reform and provide better services? So far, the answer has been no. This project proposes and interrogates the intuition that one reason for this is the informal nature of taxation in developing countries. Whether and how citizens pay taxes, and their perceptions of belonging to a group of like-minded taxpayers, conditions their political demands and the likelihood of voting on programmatic issues. For class consciousness to emerge and translate into coordinated pressure on the government, a group of individuals must first see themselves as such. I seek to show that in one stable, developing democracy -- Senegal, this is not the case. While there is a growing group of urbanites in the capital who generate enough income to satisfy their most basic demands and thus share second-order preferences such as improved education and opportunities for their children, better infrastructure and services to support their businesses, this group is fractionalized and does not perceive these commonalities. One reason for this appears to be the uneven way in which members of this so-called middle class interact with the state. While there is a more traditional middle class group of salaried individuals working in the private and public sector who often have unions and shared experiences, this group is quite small. The second, much larger group is comprised of small businesses and individual entrepreneurs, the vast majority of which exist in the informal sector. While salaried individuals are taxed regularly and systematically in accordance with the fiscal code, informal sector business owners and entrepreneurs are taxed in an erratic and informal way by the state that is often outside standard and transparent fiscal processes. Not only are the experiences of these two groups substantively different, but the informal and unsystematic nature of taxation in the latter group does not lend itself to coordination. Members of this group have little information about how others like themselves experience taxation, and since their experience is unsystematic, they have no reason to assume the experience of others will look the same. The purpose of the present data collection exercise is to validate some of these assumptions and further examine the importance of the link between taxation, class consciousness, and political participation. Specifically, I will ask four related research questions. First, do citizens presently condition their vote on fiscal policy decisions, and is this conditional on being in the formal sector? Second, does priming taxation or making certain taxes more salient change the way in which voters conceive of demands on the government or make electoral decisions? Third, does priming the ability of like-minded voters to coordinate on shared interests influence the nature of demands on government or the way in which voters formulate electoral preferences? And finally, does providing information about the costs and benefits of formalization make formalization more attractive for the informal sector?
registration_responses.q16: Hypothesis 1: Salaried members who formally pay taxes will have a qualitatively different set of demands of the government – more programmatic in nature – relative to informal sector members who informally and unsystematically pay taxes, in spite of both saying they are able to meet basic needs. They will also be more likely to vote along programmatic lines. Hypothesis 2 Salaried members who formally pay taxes will believe the government to whom they pay tax is less corrupt and more responsive relative to informal sector members who informally and unsystematically pay taxes. Hypothesis 3 Priming individuals to think about the taxes they pay will induce them to value transparency from government more. Hypothesis 4 Priming informal sector individuals to think about the taxes they pay will induce them to rate the government as less capable, while it will not have this effect on salaried individuals. Hypothesis 5 Priming salaried individuals to think about the taxes they pay will induce them to demand even more from government or become more dissatisfied with its performance and vote more along programmatic lines, while priming informal sector individuals to consider their tax payments will not have these effects. Hypothesis 6 Making salient a fiscal policy that has net benefits for an individual will increase support for the incumbent, but only if the individual pays taxes in the formal sector. Hypothesis 7 Bringing people into the tax base activates them politically, increasing expectations or holding the government more responsible. Hypothesis 8 Telling informal sector entrepreneurs about their tax obligation were they to obtain formal status, along with the decreased tax rate for that group, should lead them to respond more positively to fiscal policy, increasing their support for the incumbent. Hypothesis 9 Providing information about formal tax obligations along with information about the costs and benefits to formalize will increase interest in formalization. Hypothesis 10 Giving members of a formally taxed group information about the size of the “middle class” coalition that could potentially benefit from the 2013 legislation will provide a coordinating mechanism for a political response to the policy, thus increasing the political salience of fiscal policy and programmatic politics in general. Hypothesis 11 Giving members of an informally taxed group information about their tax obligation under the law (either the CGU or VAT), along with the information that a large proportion of others are in their same position, will provide a coordinating mechanism for political activity among those similarly frustrated by the status quo, thus increasing political engagement.

attributes.title: The Effects of Media Messages on Social Attitudes in Uganda - Survey Experiment

q1.value: The Effects of Media Messages on Social Attitudes in Uganda - Survey Experiment

q2.value: Donald Green | Anna Wilke | Jasper Jack Cooper | Susanne Baltes

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: The objective of this study is to estimate the impact of short video vignettes on the attitudes of viewers and those in their local community. Specifically, the project evaluates the impact of dramatized messages on attitudes towards three issues: stigma against women who have had abortions, domestic violence against women, and teacher absenteeism. Three short videos for each issue were produced and screened in rural Uganda, where these issues are prominent social concerns. In phase I and II of this study, the video vignettes were inserted in commercial breaks during films that were presented free of charge during two film festivals conducted in 2015 and 2016, respectively. Our experimental sample contained 56 village clusters in phase I and 112 village clusters in phase II. Village clusters were assigned to seven different treatment arms: 3 pairs of messages, 3 single-message treatments, and one pure control. This registration pertains to a survey experiment which will be conducted in the 56 village clusters that were part of the experimental sample of phase I of this study. The survey experiment is designed to test mechanisms that may be underlying the results pertaining to the effects of the intimate partner violence (IPV) messaging on outcomes measured in phase II of this study.

q16.value: The overarching hypothesis of this study is that viewers will become sensitized to the norm dramatized in the video vignettes. Our messages on domestic violence convey the norm that community members should take action to stop domestic violence when it occurs. We hypothesize that the effect of these messages on the willingness to intervene in domestic violence may be driven by four different elements of our messaging strategy: scenes designed to elicit empathy with victims of IPV (empathy - E); scenes designed to depict the risk that violence can spiral out of control (spiral - S); scenes designed to portray the benefits and downplay the costs of taking action (costs - C); scenes conveying the norm that IPV is always illegal and will be punished by the state (legal norm - N). The survey experiment is designed to test which of these elements is (most) effective in terms of sensitizing viewers to the norm that one should intervene to stop domestic violence.

q17.value: During the course of the interview, respondents will watch a video on a tablet. Outcomes and mediators will be measured through survey questions that will be asked after the respondent has watched the video. Respondents will be assigned to watch one of eleven different videos, combining five different factors. These factors are: scenes designed to elicit empathy with victims of IPV (empathy - E); scenes designed to depict the risk that violence can spiral out of control (spiral - S); scenes designed to portray the benefits and downplay the costs of taking action (costs - C); scenes conveying the norm that IPV is always illegal and will be punished by the state (legal norm - N); and finally, a placebo factor that portrays the norm that parents should come together to fight the problem of teacher absenteeism (placebo - P). We will estimate the effects of the treatment using ordinary least square regression. The main specification for estimating treatment effects will include indicators for all of the non-placebo factors (E, S, C, N). We will also estimate the treatment effects by adding to the main specification trading-center fixed effects, as well as covariates selected using the lasso regression procedure described in the PAP for phase II. Since it is possible for all of the mechanisms to operate at the same time, we will also test the joint significance of E, S, C, and N versus the placebo alternative.

attributes.title: Pre-analysis plan for: Survey experiment on electoral support for very wealthy candidates in South Africa

q1.value: Pre-analysis plan for: Survey experiment on electoral support for very wealthy candidates in South Africa

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: The experiment is part of a survey/project on poverty, inequality, redistribution, and clientelism in South Africa. The experiments deal with electoral support for very/super wealthy candidates in South Africa.

q16.value: The experiment tests a number of hypotheses pertaining to super/very wealthy candidates (competence, framing, name recognition, and clientelism)

q17.value: An experiment embedded in a nationally representative survey of adults citizens in South Africa.

q27.value: Citizen Surveys, Cape Town, South Africa

attributes.title: Effects of Party Cues on the Perceived Legitimacy for International Organizations

q1.value: Effects of Party Cues on the Perceived Legitimacy for International Organizations

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: This study explores when and to what extent party cues impact the perceived legitimacy of international organizations (IOs). It builds on and extends a stream of research interested in effects of elite communication on public opinion toward international issues and organizations (Maier et al. 2012; Guisinger and Saunders 2017; Torcal et al. 2018; Dellmuth and Tallberg 2019). This stream in turn relates to a broader literature on the effects of elite cueing and framing on public opinion (for overviews, see Druckman and Lupia 2000; Chong and Druckman 2007; Busby et al. 2018). In our earlier research, we have assessed the effects of communication by three types of elites on the popular legitimacy of IOs: national governments, civil society organizations, and IOs themselves (Dellmuth and Tallberg 2019). We found that both national governments and civil society organizations are capable of swaying people’s opinions of IOs, particularly through negative messages, while communication by IOs themselves tends to be less effective. In this study, we take our research one step further by focusing specifically on the effects of party cues on the perceived legitimacy of IOs. This is based on the intuition that party cues may function as a heuristic for citizens, not only in domestic politics (Levendusky 2010; Druckman et al. 2013; Leeper and Slothuus 2010; Brookman and Butler 2017), but also in opinion formation regarding IOs. For this purpose, we have designed two vignette experiments that tests the effects of party cues, party polarization, and partisan identity on citizen perceptions of IO legitimacy.

q16.value: We operationalize legitimacy beliefs using the measure of confidence in IOs. The experiments test three hypotheses about effects of party cues, party polarization, and partisan identity on citizens’ legitimacy beliefs vis-à-vis IOs, building on the work of Druckman et al. (2013). H1 Party cues: When partisans receive a frame sponsored by their party and a conflicting frame sponsored by another party, they will be more likely to move in the direction of their party’s frame than in the direction of the other party’s frame. H2 Party polarization: In a polarized environment, when partisans receive a frame sponsored by their own party and a conflicting frame sponsored by another party, they will be more likely to move in the direction of their party’s frame than in the direction of the other party’s frame to a greater extent than they do in a non-polarized environment. H3 Partisan identity: The strength of the effect of party cues (H1) and party polarization (H2) will be stronger among citizens with a stronger partisan identity.

q17.value: We devised two identically designed vignette experiments, which appear in the same survey. The order of the experiments is block randomized for each respondent to reduce the likelihood of spillover effects from one experiment to another. One experiment focuses on party cues regarding military spending on NATO, and the other experiment on party cues regarding reductions in the number of refugees accepted under the UN’s refugee convention. These two issues share several features that make them well suited to test our hypotheses (Druckman et al. 2013). First, both issues received attention in public debates in Germany and the US prior to our study. Second, while both issues are topically relevant, we can suspect that the public’s attention on them is not crystallized and instead somewhat conflicted, due to multiple considerations on each issue. Third, both issues are such that the main parties in Germany and the US tended to hold different positions, but not persistently dramatically opposed positions, which allowed our treatments to vary the level of party polarization. In each experiment, 2000 respondents are randomized into four treatment groups of 400 respondents each and a control group of 400 respondents. Respondents are assigned the same condition in both experiments, since we worry that the degree of party polarization will otherwise be confusing and since this design makes it easier to assess any potential spillover effects (Transue et al. 2009; Druckman et al. 2013). The five groups were assigned the following types of information, followed by the question about confidence in an IO: - Control group: only factual information on the issue - Treatment group 1: factual information on the issue + balanced frames about the main arguments on each side - Treatment group 2: factual information on the issue + balanced frames about the main arguments on each side + party endorsements - Treatment group 3: factual information on the issue + balanced frames about the main arguments on each side + party endorsements + low polarization environment - Treatment group 4: factual information on the issue + balanced frames about the main arguments on each side + party endorsements + high polarization environment It should be observed that treatment group 1 offers an alternative baseline for comparison next to the control group, since it allows us to test how respondents react to frames in the absence of party endorsements. In the US, we focused on the Democrats and the Republicans as the two main opposing parties. In Germany, we focused on the CDU/CSU and the SPD as the two main opposing parties.

q24.value: not applied, since not considered necessary for previous, similar experiments

registration_responses.q1: Effects of Party Cues on the Perceived Legitimacy for International Organizations
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to realization of outcomes
registration_responses.q15: This study explores when and to what extent party cues impact the perceived legitimacy of international organizations (IOs). It builds on and extends a stream of research interested in effects of elite communication on public opinion toward international issues and organizations (Maier et al. 2012; Guisinger and Saunders 2017; Torcal et al. 2018; Dellmuth and Tallberg 2019). This stream in turn relates to a broader literature on the effects of elite cueing and framing on public opinion (for overviews, see Druckman and Lupia 2000; Chong and Druckman 2007; Busby et al. 2018). In our earlier research, we have assessed the effects of communication by three types of elites on the popular legitimacy of IOs: national governments, civil society organizations, and IOs themselves (Dellmuth and Tallberg 2019). We found that both national governments and civil society organizations are capable of swaying people’s opinions of IOs, particularly through negative messages, while communication by IOs themselves tends to be less effective. In this study, we take our research one step further by focusing specifically on the effects of party cues on the perceived legitimacy of IOs. This is based on the intuition that party cues may function as a heuristic for citizens, not only in domestic politics (Levendusky 2010; Druckman et al. 2013; Leeper and Slothuus 2010; Brookman and Butler 2017), but also in opinion formation regarding IOs. For this purpose, we have designed two vignette experiments that tests the effects of party cues, party polarization, and partisan identity on citizen perceptions of IO legitimacy.
registration_responses.q16: We operationalize legitimacy beliefs using the measure of confidence in IOs. The experiments test three hypotheses about effects of party cues, party polarization, and partisan identity on citizens’ legitimacy beliefs vis-à-vis IOs, building on the work of Druckman et al. (2013). H1 Party cues: When partisans receive a frame sponsored by their party and a conflicting frame sponsored by another party, they will be more likely to move in the direction of their party’s frame than in the direction of the other party’s frame. H2 Party polarization: In a polarized environment, when partisans receive a frame sponsored by their own party and a conflicting frame sponsored by another party, they will be more likely to move in the direction of their party’s frame than in the direction of the other party’s frame to a greater extent than they do in a non-polarized environment. H3 Partisan identity: The strength of the effect of party cues (H1) and party polarization (H2) will be stronger among citizens with a stronger partisan identity.
registration_responses.q17: We devised two identically designed vignette experiments, which appear in the same survey. The order of the experiments is block randomized for each respondent to reduce the likelihood of spillover effects from one experiment to another. One experiment focuses on party cues regarding military spending on NATO, and the other experiment on party cues regarding reductions in the number of refugees accepted under the UN’s refugee convention. These two issues share several features that make them well suited to test our hypotheses (Druckman et al. 2013). First, both issues received attention in public debates in Germany and the US prior to our study. Second, while both issues are topically relevant, we can suspect that the public’s attention on them is not crystallized and instead somewhat conflicted, due to multiple considerations on each issue. Third, both issues are such that the main parties in Germany and the US tended to hold different positions, but not persistently dramatically opposed positions, which allowed our treatments to vary the level of party polarization. In each experiment, 2000 respondents are randomized into four treatment groups of 400 respondents each and a control group of 400 respondents. Respondents are assigned the same condition in both experiments, since we worry that the degree of party polarization will otherwise be confusing and since this design makes it easier to assess any potential spillover effects (Transue et al. 2009; Druckman et al. 2013). The five groups were assigned the following types of information, followed by the question about confidence in an IO: - Control group: only factual information on the issue - Treatment group 1: factual information on the issue + balanced frames about the main arguments on each side - Treatment group 2: factual information on the issue + balanced frames about the main arguments on each side + party endorsements - Treatment group 3: factual information on the issue + balanced frames about the main arguments on each side + party endorsements + low polarization environment - Treatment group 4: factual information on the issue + balanced frames about the main arguments on each side + party endorsements + high polarization environment It should be observed that treatment group 1 offers an alternative baseline for comparison next to the control group, since it allows us to test how respondents react to frames in the absence of party endorsements. In the US, we focused on the Democrats and the Republicans as the two main opposing parties. In Germany, we focused on the CDU/CSU and the SPD as the two main opposing parties.
registration_responses.q24: not applied, since not considered necessary for previous, similar experiments
